Matt
618 reviews
August 16, 2021
There are many rabbits in popular culture, but none of them are as tough as the rabbits in this book. Watership Down by Richard Adams chronicles a colony of survivors throughout their adventures to create a new life for themselves while avoiding predators and rabbits that have gone off the deep end.

In the Sandleford warren, Fiver, a young runt rabbit who is a seer, receives a frightening vision of his warren's imminent destruction. He and his brother Hazel fail to convince their chief rabbit of the need to evacuate, they set out on their own, accompanied by nine other rabbits who choose to go with them. After eluding the Owsla, the warren's military caste that believe they are trying to spread dissent against the chief, they make their way out into the world. Hazel quickly and suddenly finds himself the leader of the travelling group. After a series of dangerous situations, they come across a rabbit named Cowslip that invites them to join his warren. At first Hazel’s group are relieved, but soon several of them—especially Fiver—believe something is wrong which is confirmed when Bigwig is nearly killed in a snare. Fiver tells the group that Cowslip’s warren is managed by a farmer who protects and feeds the rabbits, but also harvests several of them for their meat and skins. Hazel’s group continue their journey and are joined by Strawberry, a rabbit from Cowslip’s warren. Following Fiver’s visions, the group finds a safe place to settle, the titular Watership Down. They are found by Holly, the head of the Sandleford Owlsa, and Bluebell find the group and related the violent human destruction of their former warren. Hazel soon realizes the new warren needs does or it would eventually die out. With the help of their useful new friend, a black-headed gull named Kehaar, they locate a nearby warren called Efrafa, which is overcrowded and has many does. Hazel sends a small embassy, led by Holly, to Efrafa to present their request for does. Hazel scouts the nearby Nuthanger Farm finding two pairs of hutch rabbits that express willingness to come to Watership. Hazel leads a raid on the farm the next day and rescues the does and one buck but at the cost of Hazel getting seriously injured a hind-leg. The embassy returns with news that Efrafa is a police state led by the despotic General Woundwort that they barely escaped. However, Holly's group has managed to identify an Efrafan doe named Hyzenthlay who wishes to leave the warren and can recruit other does to join in the escape. Hazel and Bigwig devise a plan to rescue Hyzenthlay's group and bring them to Watership Down; Bigwig is sent to do the mission, with infrequent help from Kehaar, and the group escape using a raft. Again, Bigwig nearly dies in the escape attempt. Once they are at Watership Down, the Efrafan escapees start their new life of freedom. Shortly thereafter, the Owsla of Efrafa, led by Woundwort himself, attacks but their surprise is ruined by Hazel’s friendship with the field mice. Through Bigwig's bravery and loyalty, and Hazel's ingenuity, the Watership Down rabbits seal the fate of the Efrafan general by unleashing the Nuthanger Farm watchdog. After the battle Woundwort is missing and Bigwig severally injured while Hazel is almost killed by one of the Nuthanger cats but saved by the farm girl Lucy. The epilogue finds Hazel visited by El-ahrairah, the spiritual overseer of all rabbits and hero of the traditional rabbit stories told over the course of the book. He invites Hazel to join his own Owsla, which Hazel does after assurance of the warren's success and its future.

How can a nearly 500-page book about rabbits be so entertaining? Is this a children’s story or just literature? Honestly, I don’t care as this book was a fantastic read from the characters to the various adventures to the unique types of warrens that Adams has the rabbits encounter and create. In any case I will never view rabbits the same again, both in a good and a bad way (they are violent little furballs).

Watership Down is a fantastic book with not only adventures but stories of adventures that inspire said rabbits. Richard Adams crafted not only a great narrative but great characters that grew throughout the book. This book was recommended this book by a friend and now I can recommend it to others as well.
    2021-reads literature
Jason Parent
Author 45 books 658 followers
May 21, 2017
Okay.

I just read a very long story about rabbits. Yes, there were several times I asked myself why I was reading a very long story about rabbits. Yes, there were times when I quoted Nick Cage from Con Air when he politely asks his fellow inmate to "Put the bunny back in the box." And yes, there were times where I saw a dead bunny on the side of the road and thought, "Maybe it's Big Wig." (no spoiler - though there is a rabbit named Big Wig, he is not hit by a car in this story). And damn there's a lot of rabbit roadkill this time of year.

Also, the title is very misleading, though you do get a small dose of water and a ship of sorts. For those who haven't read it, Watership Down is the name of a place where, apparently, lots of bunnies frolic, go on adventures, burrow holes, fight other bunnies, talk with other animals, and take a ton of shits and eat the undigested food of their friends' shits. Yeah, I looked up "pellets." Filthy little creatures.

So what's the story? Well, it starts with Johnny-Smith-Dead-Zone Bunny (aka Fiver) having a premonition that the apocalypse is coming to bunny town. Those who believe him flee, led by their leader-by-default, Hazel. Mishaps and mayhem begin, with the wholesome message that by banding together, using everyone's individual strengths for betterment of the rabbit posse, all can prevail.

And also the message that if a friend dies, forget him as soon as possible and/or pretend it never happened.

Also, eat and poop everywhere.

I am hesitant to call this a kid's story. I am also hesitant to say someone my age and without children should be reading it. Maybe it's middle grade? But hey, it was free.

And surprisingly good, with fables similar to clean versions of the Canterbury Tales (Tails?) but starring rabbits. These show up as stories within the main story that, instead of detracting from the main plot, help to enrich it.

These rabbits talk and think like humans but act only as rabbits can (for the most part). In the audiobook version the other animals talk with stereotypical European accents, which right or wrong, I found very amusing.

If I had children, I would think this would be a story I would like to read to them a chapter a night for the course of a month, once they hit the ripe age of wanting to hear a story with some substance but aren't yet too old that they no longer enjoy being read to. And still like to laugh at rabbits pooping everywhere and then re-eating the undigested parts-but really, do we ever outgrow that?

But I don't, so I'll read it to my next dog (except the parts that have dogs, because it is somewhat derogatory to their species).

A good read, a tale with heart and morals not force fed by a heavy hand. Recommended.
Aiden Heavilin
Author 1 book 69 followers
May 10, 2018
I don't know why we read stories, not really. As an author, I like theorizing on various things, the nature of good pacing, the key to realistic dialogue, the secrets of beautiful writing, but I tend to leave the big questions, (Why do we read? What are stories for? Are all stories the same?) to the philosophers and the hipsters. I don't know, the big questions about "art" and "life" don't interest me as much as observing the beauty in a turn of phrase, a nuance of characterization, a paragraph so sublimely beautiful you have to read it again on the spot. I don't have the answers to the big stuff.

Watership Down doesn't have the answers to the big questions either. The sublime wisdom in Richard Adam's message is that the big things take care of themselves. He builds his philosophy of life not from grand pronouncements but from folktales and adventures. Our job is to ford the rivers, to free the prisoners, to tell our stories, to defend our warren, to save the mouse from the hawk, to enjoy a moment with a friend in the meadow; the big things will take care of themselves. Adams tells us that there are larger forces at play; we need only perform our part and good will win. Things take care of themselves.

I live in Indiana, the suburbs, where every day is pretty much the same. Neighbors are friendly; its not a bad side of town. Thirty minutes drive takes you to the country, where you can feel the bones of the earth beneath your feet and walk forever in infinite cornfields. That's me. Elsewhere on the earth, there's kids in war-zones; artillery fire keeps them awake. Elsewhere there's a crumbling socialist government in Venezuela where The Collective determines how much food you're allowed to have, and the mafia runs entire city blocks. There's so much going on at once, so many people I'll never meet and I'll never understand. And the hard part about being a writer, the hardest, is getting myself out of my comfortable suburban mindset and trying to glimpse what its like there in the places on Earth where people think differently , value different things, fear different things, want different things. That's our job as writers, to find a way to put ourselves, and in turn our readers, into the shoes of those with the wildest experiences. We are thieves, stealing emotions we've never felt and packing them into words.

And what Adams does in this book is just that. He is able to evoke a culture radically different than our own, he's able to get into the heads of his rabbits and show us how they think. Theirs is a world of tricks and cunning, where thievery is a virtue and honesty a vice. Theirs is a world of danger at every turn, where they are hated by all but cannot be outmatched. He places himself in not just a different culture's shoes, but a different species' shoes (paws?) and evokes how it must feel to see the world from low to the ground.

Something I noticed recently is that books rarely have goosebump moments. I get goosebumps from movies all the time; be they 2001: A Space Odyssey when Hal kills the astronauts in stasis, or even a pulpy action movie like Captain America: Civil War as Steve leaves behind his shield. Big goosebump moments are quite common in the movies, but books generally leave out these massive culminations and pay-offs. Perhaps its because, in a movie, there are multiple things happening at once: swelling music, dialogue, visual effects, etc., while in a book, the author must proceed one sentence at a time. Moreover it seems to me as if authors don't try to hit that perfect sentence, that cymbal crash. Many authors are good at building mood, but not at unleashing pure awe.

But Adams creates a story that can switch between languid nature descriptions ala Thoreau and Blockbuster action with ease (it elevates both). Sure he gives us gorgeous writing and metaphors, sure he gives us some philosophizing, but he also writes zany, hilarious slapstick, fast-paced action, and, yes, goosebump moments. I can't count how many times during the finale I felt the hair rising on both arms. Adams doesn't try to be "literary" or pretentious, he's more than willing to throw in one-liners and melodramatic last stands. It's incredible.

This is and always will be one of my favorite books.
    favorites genre-is-an-insult otherworldly-atmosphere
Russ
354 reviews 35 followers
November 17, 2020
Marvelous. A special mix of enchantment and adventure—more harrowing than Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone , less encyclopedic than 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea .

Adams did such an amazing job at world-building. What an achievement to create a fantasy out of something as familiar as our own back yards! It seems so real to me now that each rabbit warren would have its own Owsla, or palace guards. And that rabbits would have their own coherent mythology about their great trickster forebear, El-ahrairah. And that some rabbits, like Fiver, would have prophetic discernment into the dangers they face.

This book is also beautifully lyric descriptions of the countryside, of flowers in bloom, and trees. It’s the descriptive sentences in the Kindle sample alone that first compelled me to want to read this book.

But if you think it will be all gentle, naturalistic descriptions and poignant tenderness among animals, think again. Each successive adventure ratchets up the suspense—like living on a knife’s edge. I felt reasonably sure when the rabbits set out from one place to the next that they could attain their objective. But I was never sure who or how many rabbits they might lose in the effort. Would it be worthwhile or a hollow victory? In this sense the novel exhibited life-and-death stakes and the best traditions of adventure fiction and even military fiction.

All these wonderful things about the book yet Adams might have a difficult time if shopping his manuscript to New York literary agents today. They are risk averse to stories where there is any possibility that an animal’s life could be in jeopardy. They also have a fixation with emotionally deep characterizations, and Hazel might come across a little too remote and no-nonsense for their contemporary tastes. Not that Hazel is a purely rational rabbit chief—his raid on Nuthanger Farm is quite impetuous.

I was not expecting such a powerful indictment of totalitarian societies as conveyed through the rival clan of rabbits in Efrafa. I had thought those tales had ended with Brave New World and 1984, and that later English authors didn’t bother critiquing what we’d all already learned about societal suffocation. But I’m very thankful that Adams did. The Watership rabbits exhibit a yearning for freedom that should resonate universally.

Yet I liked that even that nasty General Woundwort, a remarkable villain, had strengths (valor) and defenders (Groundsel) to the end.

This book kept me up later than planned on several of the nights I read it. When the day’s work is done, or some crisis has passed, the rabbits would often gather together for story time. Although several of the stories told by Dandelion weren’t that great, I can’t adequately convey the powerful atmosphere the stories conjured. I do not read by candlelight and there are no candles in the book, but there were moments where I could almost picture myself huddling up in the burrow under a warm glow of candlelight for rabbit story time!
Jason
348 reviews 46 followers
March 17, 2016
An epic adventure through the eyes of clever, proper English rabbits.

This tale is heart-warming and tensely suspenseful. The lives of rabbits are full of dangers and the author, Richard Adams, explores each of these plus a few more than would be properly expected as he follows a group of rabbits on a quest to find their own place in their world and then to protect it.

Adams manages a Herculean task quite deftly: writing a story around anthropomorphized animals without ever taking away their animality, nor for that matter, ever failing to inspire us readers to the best parts of our humanity. There is a unrelenting respect shown to animals and their nature while allowing us human interlopers to get into their beady-eyed little heads; it's a fine line that Adams successfully walks. There are obviously many divergences from natural behavior, but never to the point that you picture a waist-coated cartoon, great pains are taken to assure that a wild rabbit is always the image portrayed and perceived.

Our wild rabbits take us on a beautiful quest (and this right after I commented on another book that I am not a fan of 'quest-novels'), rich in excitement from the very beginning when a group of rabbits flee the only home they have known to establish their own warren elsewhere. Along the way, each place these rabbits come to brings them face-to-face with new challenges and different ways of living that continuously begs the question, "How much freedom will a populace be willing to give up in the name of security and/or comfort?" - an appropriate question to ponder in our own lives. Our crew eventually settle on a place to call home, but then have to risk their lives again in order to ensure the a peaceful future for the warren.

The motley cast of characters are fairly fleshed out for a novel that is meant for a younger audience. There is also a decent amount of menace and light-gore here which I found unexpected, but appropriate. I loved the intermittent oral myths about the rabbit demi-god, El-ahrairah, that were reminiscent of Brier Rabbit, as is even mentioned near the beginning of the book. And let's not forget the Lapine language that sprinkles the text with rabbit words for things that are often explicitly defined, but at other times left satisfyingly vague. All these things come together to form a book that should be taken more seriously than one might at first think. I do wish I had read it at an earlier age, but I am very happy to have finally given it the time it so rightfully deserves.

Neil R. Coulter

March 26, 2018
It often happens with books that I read and love, that I feel like writing about them almost cheapens the experience of reading and loving them. Watership Down is one of those books. It is so perfect and so beautiful that I hate to add my own inadequate words about it.

I had reached my 40s without ever having read Richard Adams's classic. I knew of it, of course, and I don't know why I hadn't read it (or even seen the 1978 animated film adaptation). But a used copy of it was sitting on our bookshelf, and one of my sons (Hi, Cameron!) picked it up and read it--not just read it, but could hardly put it down. He read it every minute he had available. When he finished it, he pleaded with me to read it aloud to everyone as bedtime stories, and I was most curious to try this book that had so grabbed his imagination.

He didn't let me down, of course--he has good taste, and this novel is unbelievably good. Adams clearly loves words--beautiful, unusual, precise words--but used in a way that doesn't draw attention to his own cleverness. The words flow naturally from Adams, and I am in awe of his lexical agility.

I love the breadth and depth of the story. It's myth-making on the level of Tolkien or anyone else who has fully created a world and a story worth telling about it. The final pages had me weepy (of course), and I can only hope that when I die, God will ask me to be part of his Owsla.

A final recommendation: If you're going to read Watership Down , then it's good to read it in a beautiful edition. We really enjoyed this illustrated hardcover from 2014, ISBN 9781780746623, which can be found for a reasonable price online.
    bedtime-reading-with-kids favorites fiction
Darrin
189 reviews
October 22, 2022
Again, a book I probably read in my teens, turns out to be so much better than when I read it the first time. One thing that I realized is that Adams' writes like a naturalist. As a kid, I never picked up on how many plant names and descriptions he put into this book and how it totally fits into the story just because we are talking rabbits here and not people.

But more than that is the story. Adams states in his introduction to this edition that we should not look for any deeper meaning in these stories and that he simply put down on paper, stories that he had been telling his children when they were young. But, really isn't that deeper meaning inherent to all good fiction? Certainly a human being can't really tell a good story without unintentionally or otherwise, bringing out the underlying, and perhaps, unconscious biases, ethics and morals of the author.

Whatever Adams intended, in the end, he not only wrote an amazing story but he also wrote a book from which we can unpack a lot of deep moral truths that ultimately tell a very "human" story which is why, in my opinion, it is so good and so enjoyable.

And here I go again tearing up at the end. Of course, if you haven't read Watership Down by now there is something wrong with you, but all the same, I won't commit any spoilers but I will say that, like Ursula LeGuin's story Firelight that ends the Earthsea sequence and the story of Ged, the story of the character Hazel just ends so well.

Do yourself a favor...if you are not dead...read this book.

I’m not sure if I read it “right”, but Watership Down seemed to me like an indictment of anthropogenic climate change and the exploitative agricultural practices of capitalism, cloaked in a children’s story with a few made up words (though Adams insists that was never his intention).

I’m glad to have read it, so I can finally “get” all those pop culture references, but I doubt I’ll be revisiting it – even if there was a kid around to read it to, I doubt I could get them to sit still for long enough.
